title: Watch CNBC's full interview with former Secretary of State Antony Blinken

rawLines.text: the president makes his speech in the
Rose Garden and puts up the board with
the tariffs and I want to know what you
were thinking as you were watching that
well first I was trying to figure out
where the numbers came from because it
wasn't exactly self-evident but look
there's obviously a case for for tariffs
that are very targeted discreet focused
on real real problems real issues
including what the president did during
his first term and putting the focus on
China right and now we've got a huge
problem with Chinese overcapacity trying
to dump things on our markets and push
our people out of business um that's
exactly where it makes sense to use
tariffs but what really struck me was of
course this wasn't focused on on that
problem this was global tariffs
including against the very countries
that we need to be with us to deal with
a problem like the problem posed by
China so that's what first struck me
this seemed to be America against the
world not America taking on discreet
problems that do require Have you gotten
phone calls from your former
counterparts if you will abroad after
this to say you know what am I supposed
to do how should I deal with this i I've
gotten I've gotten a lot of phone calls
all I can tell you though is I'm not in
the business of giving foreign leaders
advice uh but um folks who called me
former colleagues I certainly listened
to what they were saying and Andrew
here's the problem look it may be what
are they saying so first of all uh
they're if if they're allies or maybe in
some cases former allies uh they're a
gasast at uh the United States going at
them and what I'm hearing is that here's
the the I think the real challenge it's
possible that in some of these instances
there'll be a negotiation and maybe
something uh concrete and positive will
develop but the message that this is
sent to countries around the world
including some of our closest allies and
partners is we need to move away from
the United States um we can't rely on
the United States we've got to work
around the United States so we're going
to be doing more with each other and in
some cases more with China you now have
uh the EU trade uh reps meeting with
their Chinese counterparts the South
Koreans and Japanese for the first time
in 5 years meeting with their Chinese
counterparts so my concern is that this
is pushing countries that we need with
us to deal with a lot of challenges away
from us and maybe even toward China how
do you see the negotiations with China
itself playing out the president has now
talked about effectively tariffs that
could get ratcheted up to
104% effectively of the price tag of
things that are being imported into our
country well this is a an extraordinary
game of chicken because I think it's
very hard for Xiinping to to back down
or be seen as backing down so they're
going to have to find some way out of
this spiral they are or we are in effect
I think both of us because I think this
heads to a very bad place last time
around um president struck a deal with
with China china vowed to buy a lot of
stuff from us they never actually did in
part because of COVID maybe in part
because they weren't going to follow
through but there was an off-ramp uh
there needs to be some other kind of
off-ramp here that allows Xiinping to do
what he needs to do to cover himself
politically but also gets some kind of
result that the president can point to
but again I come back to this
proposition look when we're dealing with
China alone uh and there are many unfair
trade practices that everyone's very
familiar with the overcapacity problem
is real especially on cutting edge uh
technologies um but when we're dealing
with China alone we're what 20% of world
GDP when we're aligned as we were just a
few months ago with partners in Europe
partners in in East Asia we're 50 or 60%
of world GDP a lot harder for China to
ignore that's the way to get results so
I'm afraid that you know we're heading
to a place where instead of it being
America first it's America alone right
um Scott Bessant effectively uh said
that that China doesn't have the cards
that we have the leverage do
we china's in has some has some real
challenges uh we all know them on the
other hand look at what's happening the
massive investments that China is making
in its own R&D in its own technologies
in its own research at a time when
unfortunately we're also pulling back
from that uh I think is also going to
stand us in badstead going going forward
um you walk you walk around any research
university in in this country where the
innovation happens and it's like going
into the United Nations as we start to
move away from that as we make life more
difficult as grants dry up from the
government um as people start stop
coming here China's making it more and
more attractive for people to to go
there or to stay there um so they have
they have real cards to play and here's
what's happening they do they're
presenting themselves as the responsible
actor they're presenting themselves as
the the country that is for free trade
uh that is for normal economic relations
uh with uh with other countries and of
course there's a big fiction there
because of all the unfair practices
they're engaged in but by comparison um
it presents a problem for us just
finally on the off-ramp issue for for
the the China US conversation whatever
that is I imagine President Xi needs to
save some kind of face but President
Trump's going to want to be able to
proclaim that he won something that's
right so if you were to think about what
that ultimately looks like what is it
and when you think about the various
sort of chess pieces Tik Tok for example
how how do you use these pieces look you
may be able on Tik Tok to cut a deal
whereby the the Chinese allow uh
something to go ahead so that there's
new uh effective ownership of Tik Tok or
at least the algorithm which is really
what's key um maybe do you think that
they will release the algorithm because
part of this whole issue is we the US
have said over and over again that this
is a national security threat and so if
you make a deal without the algorithm it
does it doesn't work it doesn't work
look there there are variety of places
where where this could go it could mean
the Chinese buying more stuff it could
mean them ending some of the uh
overcapacity practices they've been in
where they're you know swamping um
community with uh underpriced stuff that
pushes our businesses out of business
and uh does grievous harm to our own
communities it could be something along
those lines but there has to be
something that works for both of them
and to something that you'd appreciate
we're both too big to fail right
um you know in your last speech um in
your in your role uh as Secretary of
State you talked about Germany and Japan
uh being our closest allies we are now
apparently in some form of negotiation
or conversation with Japan over these
tariffs what do you think the
relationship ultimately looks like after
this and do you think that the
toothpaste is out of the tube that the
relationship has fundamentally changed
at all uh for for countries where we
were allies or are allies whether it's
Germany or Japan or the UK given what's
happened here even just the past week
look one of the most extraordinary
developments over the last 80 years
which in the sweep of human history is
not a lot is the fact that over the last
four years when I was uh on the job
probably our two closest partners were
Germany and Japan that's an incredible
story the idea that we would put that in
doubt um is do you think it is do you
think it do you think it's genuinely in
doubt or do you think that this is
something that can be walked back from
look something has been I think
irretrievably lost now fundamentally
they still have strong interests and we
of course have a strong interest in both
partnerships but this question of trust
which is the foundation of the
partnership that has now been called
into question and so even if they think
well maybe we'll get someone uh down the
road um who does business in something
in a way that we're more used to they
really can't count on the fact that
that's going to be enduring right and
putting that genie back in the bottle is
going to be hard just real quick the art
of the deal when it comes to tariffs
there's a real question mark of how long
this could take um do you get a Brett
and Wood style kind of deal where
everybody gets involved are they all
bilateral one-offs does this go on for
months and months and months in which
case you have a paralysis in terms of
investment you have some leaders I think
looking at our country saying "Well
maybe I should wait see how see what the
courts say maybe the markets go down and
that puts pressure on you know
Republican members of the House and the
Senate to put pressure on the president
how do you see these dynamics
first it would be good to know what the
actual objective is because I've heard a
multiplicity of rationale for why we're
doing this is it to raise revenue is it
to bring manufacturing back to the
United States is it to deal with trade
imbalances uh what is it and we keep
hearing different stories so I think it
would be very helpful for the
administration to come forward and make
clear what they're actually trying to do
now if this is about what the president
has has talked about for a long time
which is this sense that other countries
to quote him are ripping us off and the
way he sees that is through trade
imbalances well it's not at all clear to
me that tariffs and and trade imbalances
are are are that closely connected um in
fact we have you know if you look at the
the 27 countries in the European Union
right uh they have the same tariffs they
have more or less the same trade
policies we've got sur trade surpluses
with some we have deficits with others
so we need to know what is this actually
about what is the president trying to
accomplish now when there's unfairness
uh and when we're trying to correct that
good we want to be strong we want to use
the right tools but we've got to do it
in a smart way and the final thing is
this look maybe this lands in in a in a
better place but meanwhile people are
getting hurt uh we're going to see
prices go up we're going to see it more
costly to export American goods at the
same time the people who are really
going to bear the brunt of that will be
consumers who are in the middle class
and the lower class for whom the price
of basic things is going to go up and
for American manufacturers Andrew and
you know this so well yeah great we want
more American exports except that so
many of our exports have components that
are coming from somewhere else if their
prices go up our prices go up and we'll
be less competitive is there any way in
your mind this could end well
at this point um I think
maybe there are some some deals where
there are egregious uh imbalances maybe
they get corrected but I am more than
deeply concerned that the message that
we've sent to the world is you can't
count on you can't trust America and the
reason net result of that is they'll be
looking for ways to work around us away
from us and that's not going to be good
for us um want to pivot to uh Iran for
just a moment president Trump saying
that the US will have direct talks uh
with Iran on Saturday apparently to
discuss a nuclear deal iran officials
are saying that this is not going to be
a direct conversation it will be a
indirect conversation what do you think
is really happening well first if there
if there are talks whether they're
direct or indirect or indirect I applaud
that because it's it's good if we're
talking and it's good if we're trying to
do something about the nuclear program
my sense is that President Trump would
like a deal he'd prefer to get a deal
than to have to use military means one
he doesn't want another war two military
means in dealing with their nuclear
program less effective than actually
having a durable agreement and we had
that agreement right we had the
agreement that President Obama reached
uh we had their nuclear program in a box
unfortunately President Trump tore it up
at the time he said that he was going to
produce a better deal he didn't now
there's an opportunity and why is there
an opportunity because Iran is at its
weakest point in a long time why is that
the case in large part because of the
work that we were able to do with Israel
both to protect Israel from the attacks
that it endured from Iran bringing
together a whole coalition of countries
including in the region to defend Israel
and also to work with Iran with Israel
on calibrating its response so that it
took out Iran's missile uh air defenses
uh and it put Iran in the weakest
position iran's lost its proxies in um
in Hezbollah uh in Hamas in Assad and
Syria this is the moment for a deal and
I hope that the president seizes it when
you think about Israel and you think
about getting the hostages back and this
is something I know you worked so very
hard on how much credit do you think you
and uh the Biden administration deserve
how much credit do you believe that the
Trump administration deserves for the
hostages that that came back on his
during his tenure well look I'm more
than happy to to share the credit
because the most important thing is the
result the result that we had for for
six weeks hostages back uh conflict uh
held in obeyance Palestinians getting
the assistance that they so desperately
need it's a wonderful thing that that
happened after so much trauma so much
tragedy so much suffering now the deal
itself was the deal that President Biden
uh put out there uh we negotiated uh we
got done but I'm glad we worked actually
very closely with with Steve Whit in the
end to get it over the finish line but
here's the problem that produced a six-w
week ceasefire uh it got hostages back
but there had to be something that
followed in order for that ceasefire to
be enduring we put down a plan and we
left a plan for the next administration
for how to make it enduring uh bringing
in the Arabs bringing in other partners
to try to fill the fill the vacuum so
that Israel could leave Gaza and Hamas
wouldn't fill in unfortunately more more
than unfortunately tragically that seems
to have been dropped um I want to ask
you about Ukraine really actually wanted
to ask you when you watched the press
conference with President Trump and
Vance and Zilinski again it's a similar
question to maybe the Rose Garden
ceremony what were you thinking as you
watched that unfold given that you know
all of these people so well
look you know we spent so much time so
much effort on working to defend Ukraine
against this extraordinary onslaught
from from Russia and the reason for that
was twofold one you don't want to see a
smaller nation bullied by a bigger one i
think Americans don't like that but this
was always bigger than Ukraine it was
really about the aggression not just
against Ukrainians but against the
principles that kind of underly the
international system that one nation
can't go in and change the borders of
its neighbor by force can't pretend to
uh dictate what that neighbor is going
to do um and if we had allowed that to
go forward with impunity then it would
have been a Pandora's box opened up
around the world for every wouldbe
aggressor who would have said "If Putin
can get away with it so can I." So it
was so important that we stand strongly
with Ukraine to prevent more conflict to
prevent more aggression and we did that
now there is an opportunity to get this
to a better place to a ceasefire and if
the president can do that great but
here's what it requires it requires
making sure that if there is a ceasefire
that the Ukrainians have the means to
deter future Russian aggression because
one thing I can tell you for sure
Putin's not given up on his ambitions to
erase Ukraine from the map to subsume it
into Russia he'll rest he'll refit and
reattack if given the opportunity so
you've got to have deterrence built in
you've got to have real protection that
can be done in a number of ways the
Europeans are willing they've said to
put forces on a demarcation line but
they need backup from the United States
but people who watched that press
conference it was almost like a roar
shack test some people looked at that
and said that Zilinsky was effectively
goating Vance and goating Trump uh into
this and others felt that it was the
opposite that it that it was Vance
goating Zalinski what did you see look I
think who whichever way it is um we
shouldn't be in the business of goating
each other andor we shouldn't be in the
business of taking the bait if goating
is going on because the stakes are too
great for that look did we have
frustrations occasionally with um our
Ukrainian friends including President
Zilinski sure did we show that in public
when it happened no because it's so
important that there be a clear united
front and you can't lose sight of the
fundamental which is there's an
aggressor and that's Russia there's a
victim and that's Ukraine and it's
unfortunate that the focus got taken off
of that in fair to ask for or try to
take rare earth uh you know minerals or
other kinds of renumeration for our help
yes in fact part of the the victory
package that President Zilinsky put on
the table in the last 6 months of our
administration included um us working
with them on rare earths on critical
minerals and we've been trying to drive
investment in Ukraine including in that
sector for many months and it would be
something that would be beneficial to
our companies but what I think we saw
put forward in the in the deal that was
proposed was basically a protection
racket without the protection uh we want
all of this stuff but you're really not
going to get much for it in terms of
protection against Russia from us okay
one one or two more signal gate
what did you think well as somebody as
somebody who lives this who knows this
who who's been on various chains and
threads before um how concerned were you
uh very concerned because as I as I saw
it this was using signal among other
things to share very active operational
plans um and is the problem using signal
or is the problem who was on the list
meaning should all of those people been
getting this kind of information in real
time this way there it may be that there
were one or two or three people who
arguably shouldn't have been on it no it
it it it was using signal and look
everyone wants to be able to communicate
effectively in real time i get that i I
know that and most of us I have a I used
to have in my home uh a secure room so
that if I was not in the office and if I
needed to have a secure call like the
the one they were on via signal um I'd
be able to do that we've got phones in
our cars that are secure and yeah
there's a little bit more of a a burden
in not being able to pull your phone out
of your pocket and get on signal you
have to go to a secure location but I
would say that the burden on our F-16
pilots who are carrying out the hard
work of securing the country is a little
bit greater than that and the folks who
have to protect them by maintaining
secrecy just need to focus on doing that
finally what have you thought of Doge
and what Elon Musk has been doing
whether it touches USAD which is
something obviously that I imagine you
touched in your in your old role look
can government work more efficiently of
course are there savings to be had of
course do we need to look at that sure
but to do it with a 2x4 uh instead of a
scalpel to do it in a way that um just
um shoots first and maybe ask questions
later I don't think is the way to do it
i know it's not the way to do it and
look I know that you know politically
people would love to see some of us out
there trying to defend government trying
to defend foreign assistance because
they know the American people may not be
so enamored of that but here's the
reality aid i went around the world for
four years more than that in previous
jobs and the one thing that I saw in
country after country was the powerful
impact that aid was having in bettering
people's lives now some people said that
was a char like a charity i mean they
look at the they'd look at the items and
they'd say you know Sesame Street in
Iraq why are we doing that yeah so two
things first it's one penny on every
dollar right you ask Americans how much
they think we're spending on foreign
assistance they say "Oh we're probably
spending 25% of the budget what should
we be spending 10% what are we actually
spending 1% so it's not a lot but the
return on that in terms of our own
well-being our own security uh is
dramatic when you're using that money to
make sure that um people might be a
little bit better fed that they can get
a vaccine um that they have some
opportunity in their lives that makes it
less likely that you're going to see a
war break out uh you're going to get a
mass migration maybe heading toward the
United States a pandemic that winds up
biting us all of those things have
powerful positive impacts on the United
States and of course the goodwill that
it builds for us around the world is
extraordinary i saw that again and again
the thing Andrew that I that that I
feared the most in looking at the
competition was China was the day that
China would figure out soft power and I
thought that would really make them um
even more competitive with us the idea
that we would not only see China try to
develop more soft power that that we
would seed our
own again not good for the country not
good for our interests
